sen.j: 袞衣（こんえ、こんい）は、唐風の天皇衣装。
sen.e: Kone (also pronounced Koni) is an emperor's costume in Tang style.
Kone (also pronounced Koni) is the Japanese name given to an emperor's costume in the Tang style.
sen.cmt: There is no need to have a space after the opening parenthesis or before the closing one.
sen.e: Kone (also pronounced Koni) is the Japanese name given to an emperor's costume in the Tang style.

sen.j: 礼服 (宮中)の一種で、天子御礼服ともいう。
sen.e: It is a kind of ceremonial robe (in the imperial court) and is called Tenshi Go-raifuku (Imperial Prince's ceremonial robe).
A kind of ceremonial robe (worn in the imperial court), it is also called a Tenshi Go-raifuku (Imperial Prince's ceremonial robe).
A kind of ceremonial robe (worn in the imperial court), it is also called a Tenshi Go-raifuku (Imperial Prince's ceremonial robe).

sen.j: 孝明天皇までは、即位の儀などに冕冠とともに用いられた。
sen.e: Until Emperor Komyo, it had been used with Benkan (an emperor's ceremonial crown) for accession ceremonies and so on.
Until Emperor Komyo, it was worn with the Benkan (the emperor's ceremonial crown) for accession ceremonies and so on.
Until the Emperor Komyo, it was worn with the Benkan (an emperor's ceremonial crown) for accession ceremonies and so on.
sen.cmt: Emperor Komyoの前にtheを挿入しました。emperor'sの前のtheをanに変更しました。

sen.j: 冕冠と合わせて袞冕（こんべん）ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called Konben together with Benkan.
It is also called a Konben when it is worn together with the Benkan.
It is also called a Konben when it is worn together with the Benkan.

sen.j: 袞衣は、袞服、冕服、天子御礼服とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Kone is also called Konfuku, Benfuku or Tenshi-Go-raifuku.
Kone is also called Konfuku, Benfuku or Tenshi-Go-raifuku.
Kone is also called Konfuku, Benfuku or Tenshi-Go-raifuku.

sen.j: 日本における袞衣の起源は不明であるが、『続日本紀』に「天平四年（732年）正月乙巳朔、大極殿に御して朝を受く。天皇始めて冕服を服す」とあることから、少なくとも奈良時代まで遡ると考えられている。
sen.e: Although the origin of Kone in Japan is unknown, it is believed to date at least as far back as to Nara period because it is written in "Shoku-Nihongi" which is the sequel to "Nihon Shoki"(Chronicles of Japan) that 'the Emperor wearing Benfuku for the first time showed up in the Daigokuden (Grand Palace) to receive New Year's greetings around 10 o'clock on January 1, 732 A.D.'
sen.cmt: 『続日本紀』は『日本書紀』の続編であることを挿入しました。A.D.を挿入しました。
sen.e: Although the origin of Kone in Japan is unknown, it is believed to date at least as far back as the Nara period because it is written in "Shoku-Nihongi," which is the sequel to "Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan)" that 'the Emperor wearing Benfuku for the first time showed up in the Daigokuden (Grand Palace) to receive New Year's greetings at about 10 o'clock on January 1, 732 A.D.'

Although the origin of Kone in Japan is unknown, it is believed to date at least as far back as the Nara period because it is written in "Shoku-Nihongi," which is the sequel to "Nihon Shoki" (Chronicles of Japan) that 'the Emperor wearing Benfuku for the first time showed up in the Daigokuden (Grand Palace) to receive New Year's greetings at about 10 o'clock on January 1, 732 A.D.'
sen.cmt: ()を" "の外に移動しました。歴は変更していません。英訳に合わせ、原文を後列のセルと合体させました。

sen.j: 大袖
sen.e: Osode
Osode
Osode

sen.j: 赤地に、袞冕十二章のうち、日、月、七星、山、火、龍、華虫（キジ）、宗彝の8種の模様が付く。
sen.e: Eight kinds of patterns, namely Sun, Moon, Seven Stars, Mountain, Fire, Dragon, Kachu (pheasant), and Soi (ritual article) out of Konben 12-Sho (Symbols) are attached to the red cloth of the costume.
Eight kinds of patterns--Sun, Moon, Seven Stars, Mountain, Fire, Dragon, Kachu (pheasant), and Soi (ritual article)--out of Konben 12-Sho (symbols) are attached to the red cloth of the costume.
Eight kinds of patterns--Sun, Moon, Seven Stars, Mountain, Fire, Dragon, Kachu (pheasant), and Soi (ritual article)--out of Konben 12-Sho (symbols) are attached to the red cloth of the costume.

sen.j: 各模様は刺繍のように見えるが、実際は取り外し可能になっている。
sen.e: Each pattern looks like embroidering, but actually it is detachable.
Each of the patterns resembles embroidery but is actually detachable.
Each of the patterns resembles embroidery but is actually detachable.

sen.j: 日：照臨無私を象徴。
sen.e: Sun: symbolizes 'enlightening without selfishness.'
Sun: Symbolizes 'enlightenment without selfishness.'
Sun: Symbolizes 'enlightenment without selfishness.'

sen.j: 左肩に配され、日の中に烏が描かれている。
sen.e: It is placed on the left shoulder and contains a crow drawn inside.
It is placed on the left shoulder and contains a crow drawn inside.
It is placed on the left shoulder and contains a crow drawn inside.

sen.j: 月：照臨無私を象徴。
sen.e: Moon: symbolizes 'enlightening without selfishness.'
Moon: Symbolizes 'enlightenment without selfishness.'
Moon: Symbolizes 'enlightenment without selfishness.'

sen.j: 右方に配され、月の中に兎と蟾蜍（ヒキガエル）が描かれている。
sen.e: It is placed on the right shoulder and contains a rabbit and a hoptoad drawn inside.
It is placed on the right shoulder and contains a rabbit and a hoptoad drawn inside.
It is placed on the right shoulder and contains a rabbit and a hoptoad drawn inside.

sen.j: 七星：照臨無私を象徴。
sen.e: Seven Stars: symbolizes 'enlightening without selfishness.'
Seven Stars: Symbolizing 'enlightenment without selfishness.'
Seven Stars: Symbolizing 'enlightenment without selfishness.'

sen.j: 北斗七星を背上部に配する。
sen.e: Triones are placed on the upper back part.
Triones are placed on the upper back part.
Triones are placed on the upper back part.

sen.j: 山：鎮定、雲の湧出、雨露の恵みの象徴。
sen.e: Mountain: symbolizes pacification, formation of cloud and blessing of rain.
Mountain: Symbolizes pacification, the formation of clouds and the blessing of rain.
Mountain: Symbolizes pacification, the formation of clouds and the blessing of rain.

sen.j: 身の前後に配する。
sen.e: It is placed on the front and back of the contume's main part.
It is placed on the front and back of the costume's main part.
It is placed on the front and back of the costume's main part.

sen.j: 龍：神変不可思議の霊物。
sen.e: Dragon: it is a spiritous thing of miraculous change wonder;
Dragon: A spiritous thing of miraculous change and wonder
Dragon: A spiritous thing of miraculous change and wonder

sen.j: 袖部前後に大型の巻龍、身の前後に小龍を配する。
sen.e: Large coiled dragons are placed on the front and back of each sleeve, and small dragons on the front and back of the costume's main part.
Large coiled dragons are placed on the front and back of each sleeve, and small dragons are placed on the front and back of the costume's main part.
Large coiled dragons are placed on the front and back of each sleeve, and small dragons are placed on the front and back of the costume's main part.

sen.j: 華虫：雉の意、その羽の美麗さから。
sen.e: Kachu (brightly colored bird): means a pheasant as it has beautiful wings.
Kachu (brightly colored bird): Represents a pheasant, as it has beautiful wings.
Kachu (brightly colored bird): Represents a pheasant, as it has beautiful wings.

sen.j: 身の前後に配する。
sen.e: Pheasants are placed on the front and back of the main part.
Pheasants are placed on the front and back of the main part.
Pheasants are placed on the front and back of the main part.

sen.j: 宗彝：祭器に描かれた虎（勇）、猿（智）で、祭器の象徴。
sen.e: Soi: tigers (courage) and monkeys (wisdom) which symbolize ritual articles as they are drawn on their surfaces.
Soi: Tigers (courage) and monkeys (wisdom), which symbolize ritual articles as they are drawn on their surfaces.
Soi: Tigers (courage) and monkeys (wisdom), which symbolize ritual articles as they are drawn on their surfaces.

sen.j: 身の前後下部に配する。
sen.e: They are placed on the front and back of the lower main part.
They are placed on the front and back of the lower main part.
They are placed on the front and back of the lower main part.

sen.j: 裳
sen.e: Mo
Mo
Mo

sen.j: 大袖と同じ赤地に、袞冕十二章のうち、藻、粉米、斧、黻（ふつ、亜字の形）の四種の模様が付く。
sen.e: Four kinds of patterns, namely Mo (algae), Funmai (powdered rice), Ono (ax) and Futsu (shape like 亜), out of Konben 12-Sho are attached to the same red cloth as Osode.
Four kinds of patterns--Mo (algae), Funmai (powdered rice), Ono (ax) and Futsu (shape like 亜)--out of Konben 12-Sho are attached to the same red cloth as Osode.
Four kinds of patterns--Mo (algae), Funmai (powdered rice), Ono (ax) and Futsu (shape like 亜)--out of Konben 12-Sho are attached to the same red cloth as Osode.
